task.title: Install the MidoNet Cluster on the Cloud Controller (CLC)
task.shortdesc: This topic describes how to install the MidoNet Cluster.

taskbody.context:
MidoNet management services provide a means to manage MidoNet functions that MidoNet agents (Midolman) are unable to perform on their own; MidoNet Cluster services include state synchronization of VxLAN gateways and the MidoNet REST API. A MidoNet v5 deployment requires at least one MidoNet cluster node, and since it replaces the MidoNet API webapp (which was hosted by tomcat in MidoNet v1 series), it must be co-located on the CLC host machine in deployments.
For security reasons, the MidoNet REST API is accessed only on the CLC (localhost interface).

task.title: Install Midolman on components
task.shortdesc: This topic describes how to install the Midolman agent.

taskbody.context:
Midolman is the MidoNet Agent, which is a daemon that runs on all hosts where traffic enters and leaves MidoNet. The Midolman agent is required on the Cloud Controller (CLC), Node Controllers (NCs), and any host that is a MidoNet Gateway node (e.g., UFS).
To install Midolman agent

step.cmd: Edit the /etc/midolman/midolman.conf file to set the ZooKeeper host IP(s). Replace ZOOKEEPER_HOST_IP in the following example:

info.codeblock: systemctl enable midolman.service systemctl start midolman.service

step.cmd: Configure a Midolman resource usage template.

info.p: For large clouds, use the agent-compute-large template. For standard (small or medium) clouds, use the default template. For gateway nodes, use the agent-gateway templates.

p.note: For production environments, large templates are recommended.

task.title: Create a tunnel zone in MidoNet and add hosts
task.shortdesc: This topic describes how to create a MidoNet tunnel zone.

taskbody.context:
In MidoNet, a tunnel zone is an isolation zone for hosts. Physical hosts that are members of a given tunnel zone communicate directly with one another and establish network tunnels as needed, and on demand. These network tunnels are used to transport overlay traffic (e.g., inter-VM communication) and isolate the underlying physical network communication (i.e., inter-physical hosts communication). On a deployment, one MidoNet tunnel zone is expected with the IP address on the physical network designated to carry VM traffic being used when configuring its members. accepts the following tunnel zone names:
eucatz
euca-tz
midotz
mido-tz
For more information, see What are Tunnel Zones?
To create a tunnel zone in MidoNet

step.cmd: Log into the MidoNet shell. For example:

info.codeblock: [root@clcfrontend mido-docs]# midonet-cli -A --midonet-url=http://127.0.0.1:8080/midonet-api midonet> tunnel-zone add name eucatz type gre midonet> tunnel-zone list tzone tzone0 name eucatz type gre midonet> host list host host0 name node1 alive true host host1 name clcfrontend alive true host host2 name node2 alive true

info.p: You should see a host listed for each of your Node Controllers and for your User Facing Service host; if not, check the /var/log/midolman/midolman.log log file on the missing hosts to ensure there are no error messages.

step.cmd: After verifying all your hosts are listed, add each host to your tunnel zone as follows. Replace HOST_N_IP with the IP of your Node Controller or User Facing Service host that you used to register the component with :

info.codeblock: midonet> tunnel-zone tzone0 add member host host0 address HOST_0_IP midonet> tunnel-zone tzone0 add member host host1 address HOST_1_IP midonet> tunnel-zone tzone0 add member host host2 address HOST_2_IP

taskbody.postreq: You are now ready to install and configure to use this MidoNet installation.
